data.name: Researcher impact (h-index)
data.description:
The h-index is a metric that aims to measure the impact of a researcherâ€™s published work.\
One can calculate their h-index based on a list of the number of citations for each publication.\
The h-index is determined to be the highest number of publications with a given number of citations.\
See the following examples:

| h-index       |                                               |
| ------------- |:-------------:                                |
| 0             | 0 publications with 0 citations.              |
| 1             | 1 publication with minimum 1 citation.        |
| 2             | 2 Publications each with minimum 2 citations. |
| 3             | 3 Publications each with minimum 3 citations. |
| N             | N publications each with minimum N citations. |



Problem definition

Create a function named hindex that takes as input a vector of arbitrary length. Each element in the vector corresponds to the number of citations
for a given publication.\
The function should return the calculated h-index given the vector with citations.\
You can assume that the vector only contains integers greater than or equal to zero.\
Input, c:\
Vector containing the number of citations per publication (vector).\
Output, h:\
The calculated h-index (integer)\
Example\
Consider the following input vector:\
c = [10, 8, 2, 5, 4, 1, 0, 1, 0]\
The vector shows that a researcher has a total of 9 publications.\
The first publication has 10 citations, the next publication has 8 citations, the next 2 citations and so on.\
We can start by sorting the vector from high to low:\
c = [10, 8, 5, 4, 2, 1, 1, 0, 0]\
Then we can check how many elements that fulfil the requirement of N publications each with minimum N citations:\
It turns out that 4 is the highest number of publications with minimum 4 citations.\
The h-index is therefore calculated to be h = 4.\
Other examples:\

| c             |       h        |
| ------------- |:-------------: |
| [1, 1, 0]     |       1        |
| [0, 0]        |       0        |
